basics.name: Jacob Horton
basics.label: Software Engineer
basics.summary:
I am a diligent, motivated and high-achieving individual with a strong interest in coding and servers. I especially love logical thinking and problem-solving. Furthermore, I am fluent in a range of programming languages and am always looking to learn new things.

I have used my approachability and interpersonal skills to help my friends and coworkers understanding in various topics, being commended on my ability to break complex ideas down into manageable chunks.

work.name: SparkLayer
work.summary: Worked as a full stack software engineer on a B2B e-commerce platform. Also helped out in customer support. Despite being an intern, I got to lead a project, design and implement an API/microservice from scratch, carry out a migration to a new system without downtime, update infrastructure, and much more. I learned loads about GCP, microservices, new frameworks/languages, working in a team + communication both with customers and within the team.
highlights: Presentation on APIs + how to use them for our customer support team
Communicating with enterprise clients to integrate them with our APIs
Organised a mini hackathon for the developers
Frontend - TypeScript/JavaScript + Vue + SolidJS + Lit + Haunted

projects.name: Mario Kart Scoreboard
projects.description: I developed a web app to show a scoreboard and stats of Mario Kart games. Through this project, I learned how to structure the front-end and back-end of a web app, using Rust and TypeScript + React. I did a dive into learning how authentication is handled using JWTs, access tokens and refresh tokens. I researched security for the authentication and found a middle-ground between complexity and security that I was happy with for this hobby project.
highlights: Built with React, Rust and Postgres
Learned how to structure RESTful APIs
Used Cloudflare Tunnels + set up firewall

projects.name: Homelab
projects.description:
I built a server to self-host many pieces of free and open-source software using Proxmox, Docker, and Linux. This has greatly improved my Linux and networking skills, taught me a multitude of server technologies, and given me an insight into security considerations. I am always looking for new things learn and run on this server

I also used a Raspberry Pi to create a remote-control socket switch using relays. It incorporated a Node JS server controlled via my Home Assistant server. This project taught me a lot about hardware and circuits.
